head.title: Three-Dimensional Honeycomb-Like Cu0.81Co2.19O4 Nanosheet Arrays Supported by Ni Foam and Their High Efficiency as Oxygen Evolution Electrodes | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Three-Dimensional Honeycomb-Like Cu0.81Co2.19O4 Nanosheet Arrays Supported by Ni Foam and Their High Efficiency as Oxygen Evolution Electrodes

We prepare three-dimensional honeycomb-like Cu0.81Co2.19O4 nanosheet arrays supported by Ni foam via electrochemical codeposition of cobalt and copper hydroxides on Ni foam followed by thermal oxidation. The codeposition with Cu changes the morphology of the cobalt hydroxide deposit to form honeycomb-like nanostructures, significantly decreasing the onset potential for oxygen evolution. The Cu0.81Co2.19O4 anode displays an exceptionally low overpotential of 290 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm–2 in 1 M KOH, and an anion-exchange membrane water electrolysis cell employing the above anode achieves a current density of 100 mA cm–2 at 1.68 V in 0.1 M KOH.

div.p:
We prepare three-dimensional honeycomb-like Cu
0.81
Co
2.19
O
4
nanosheet arrays supported by Ni foam via electrochemical codeposition of cobalt and copper hydroxides on Ni foam followed by thermal oxidation. The codeposition with Cu changes the morphology of the cobalt hydroxide deposit to form honeycomb-like nanostructures, significantly decreasing the onset potential for oxygen evolution. The Cu
0.81
Co
2.19
O
4
anode displays an exceptionally low overpotential of 290 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm
–2
in 1 M KOH, and an anion-exchange membrane water electrolysis cell employing the above anode achieves a current density of 100 mA cm
–2
at 1.68 V in 0.1 M KOH.

div.span: KEYWORDS:

div.p:
Despite the importance of electrolytic water splitting for mitigating environmental pollution caused by fossil fuel combustion, the high overpotentials of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at the anode result in sluggish kinetics and decreased efficiency of the water-splitting reaction, thus hindering the commercialization of hydropower.
(1)
Although IrO
2
and RuO
2
are considered to be theoretically ideal OER catalysts,
(2,3)
their widespread use is hindered by their scarcity and high cost. Therefore, alkaline-electrolyte-based water electrolysis systems, allowing the use of inexpensive and naturally abundant compounds such as transition-metal oxides,
(2,4)
phosphides,
(5−8)
and borates
(9,10)
as OER electrocatalysts, have received considerable attention. Among these materials, Co
3
O
4
is exceptionally well suited for OER in alkaline media,
(3)
featuring high catalytic activity that can be further increased by techniques such as nanostructure synthesis,
(8,11−13)
hybridization with carbon nanomaterials,
(14)
and doping with early transition metals.
(15)
In particular, Cu doping can greatly enhance the catalytic activity of Co
3
O
4
by distorting the cation distribution within the catalyst structure and raising its surface energy.
(16,17)

Another important point to consider in the OER catalyst design is the accumulation of oxygen bubbles on the catalyst surface, which can significantly deteriorate the OER rate by reducing the surface area of the electrolyte–catalyst interface.
(18)
Therefore, in order for fast oxygen evolution to be sustained, oxygen bubbles must be continuously transferred from the internal free volume of the electrode to the bulk electrolyte. Substrates with micron-sized pores (e.g., metallic foams) are frequently used for this purpose because this design provides pathways for the facile transport of oxygen bubbles.
(19,20)
In previous works, electrodeposition has been frequently suggested as an effective way to create evenly distributed catalyst layers on substrates with complex pore structures.

Herein, three-dimensional (3D) honeycomb-like Cu
0.81
Co
2.19
O
4
nanosheet arrays supported by Ni foam (NF) were prepared by electrochemical codeposition of copper and cobalt hydroxides (in a bath containing respective metal nitrates) and subsequent annealing.

Cobalt and copper oxides individually electrodeposited on NF exhibited a typical tissue/island-like appearance (
Figure S1
), as reported previously,
(21)
while codeposition afforded uniform layers of 3D honeycomb-like cross-linked nanosheets (CCHO;
Figure
1
a) except for the partial formation of a Cu-rich phase on the NF edge (
Figure S2
). The nanosheet thickness and average honeycomb cell diameter were estimated as ∼20 and 140 nm, respectively, and cross-sectional imaging (
Figure
1
b) allowed the thickness of the deposit to be estimated as ∼550 nm. Subsequently, as-deposited CCHO was annealed to form copper–cobalt oxide (CCO), which inherited the morphology of its precursor (
Figure
1
c). However, X-ray diffraction provided no evidence of annealing-induced phase transformations (
Figure S3
).

Figure 1. SEM images of (a) CCHO and (b) CCO. Inset: High-resolution SEM images. (c) Cross-sectional SEM image of CCO. (d) High-resolution TEM images of CCO and corresponding elemental mappings of (e) Co and (f) Cu. The inset of part d shows the SAED patterns of CCO.

To gain more structural information, CCO was scratched off from the NF substrate and imaged by high-resolution TEM, which revealed the presence of aggregated two-dimensionally grown nanoplates (
Figure
1
d). The Cu:Co atomic ratio was determined as 0.58 based on the results of energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) analysis, and all constituent elements were shown to be uniformly distributed (
Figures
1
e,f); i.e., almost all deposit surfaces were expected to contribute to the catalytic evolution of oxygen gas in practical electrolysis devices. Selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns of CCO were indexed to polycrystalline Co
3
O
4
and/or Co
x
Cu
3–
x
O
4
(inset of
Figure
1
d). However, the formation of the latter phase could not be unambiguously confirmed by structural analysis; that is, the patterns could not be clearly separated because both Co
3
O
4
and Cu
x
Co
3–
x
O
4
have the same spinel structure and nearly identical unit cell parameters (
a
=
b
=
c
= 8.055 Å for Co
3
O
4
and 8.140 Å for CuCo
2
O
4
).

The prepared samples were further characterized by Raman spectroscopy to obtain more information on the formation of Co
x
Cu
3–
x
O
4
because the positions of the Raman peaks were expected to depend on the Cu content (
Figure
2
a).
(22)
For comparison, cobalt hydroxide deposits (presented in
Figure
1
a) were also heat-treated to form the spinel Co
3
O
4
(labeled as CO) and examined. In the wavenumber range of 100–800 cm
–1
, the spectrum of CO featured broad Raman peaks at 200, 470, 510, 600, and 670 cm
–1
that corresponded to red-shifted signals of the typical Co
3
O
4
.
(23)
Considering the fact that the Raman spectra of CO nanoparticles showed similar shifts and broadening,
(24)
this red shift was obviously caused by the nanoscale nature of CO. In agreement with previous reports, the spectrum of CCO was red-shifted relative to that of Co
3
O
4
to an even greater extent because of the incorporation of Cu to form Co
x
Cu
3–
x
O
4
.
(22)
Figure 2. (a) Raman spectra of CCO and CO. (b) Co 2p and (c) Cu 2p XPS spectra of CCHO and CCO.

The oxidation states of Cu and Co in CCHO and CCO were examined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS;
Figures
2
b,c and
S7a,b
), which revealed that, in CCHO, Co comprised 66 atom % Co
2+
and 34 atom % Co
3+
,
(25)
whereas Cu comprised 13 atom % Cu
+
and 87 atom % Cu
2+
.
(26)
Therefore, CCHO was concluded to be a mixture of Co
3
O
4
, Co(OH)
2
, Cu(OH)
2
, and CuOH. After heat treatment, i.e., in CCO, the above compositions changed to 61/39 atom % Co
2+
/Co
3+
and 40/60 atom % Cu
+
/Cu
2+
. The Cu:Co atomic ratio was determined as 0.71, in rough agreement with the value obtained by EDS. Thus, on the basis of the combined results of Raman and XPS analyses, Co
3
O
4
, Co(OH)
2
, Cu(OH)
2
, and CuOH transformed into Cu
x
Co
3–
x
O
4
after heat treatment, and excess Cu was converted into Cu
2
O. Therefore, CCO comprised Cu
0.81
Co
2.19
O
4
and Cu
2
O precipitates on its surface.

Figure
3
a displays the first-cycle linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves of CCO, CCHO, CO, and NF, demonstrating the appearance of a potential shoulder at 1.45 V versus RHE, which was ascribed to the oxidation of Ni
2+
to Ni
3+
.
(26)
This shoulder was more clearly observed in the Tafel plots shown in
Figure
3
b. Because the Ni oxidation peak was sufficiently small to be ignored and its potential was relatively low enough to be distinguishable from that of the OER, this peak was assumed not to have any effect on further OER at higher potentials. As for CCHO, a peak corresponding to the oxidation of Co(OH)
2
to Co
3
O
4
was observed at 1.39 V.
(27−29)
For CCO, CCHO, CO, and NF, the OER onset potentials were determined as 1.50, 1.50, 1.57, and 1.60 V, respectively.

Figure 3. (a) LSV polarization curves of CCHO, CCO, CO, and NF recorded in 1 M KOH at a scan rate of 5 mV s
–1
. (b) Tafel plots derived from the above polarization curves. (c) Chronopotentiometric curves of CCO recorded at constant current densities of 25 and 100 mA cm
–2
. (d) LSV polarization curves of CCO samples subjected to 24 h of stability testing at current densities of 25 and 100 mA cm
–2
. Surface SEM images of CCO after 24 h of stability testing at current densities of (e) 25 and (f) 100 mA cm
–2
. The inset shows the corresponding high-resolution SEM images.

The Cu-incorporation-induced decrease of the onset potential was explained by (a) the very large surface area of CCO and the resulting abundance of active sites and (b) the disordered cation distribution in the spinel Co
3
O
4
caused by Cu doping and the resulting increase of the catalyst surface energy and exchange current density.
(16)
The Tafel slopes of CCO and CO approximately equaled 60 mV dec
–1
; i.e., the rate-determining step of the OER involved an OH
–
intermediate coverage step after the first electron-transfer step (
Figure
3
b).
(17)
Interestingly, the Tafel slope of CCO was slightly larger than that of CO, which could not be clearly explained despite the fact that a similar trend has already been reported in the literature.
(12)

The decreased OER onset potential of CCHO was explained in the same manner. In the first LSV curve (
Figure S8
), Co(OH)
2
and Cu(OH)
2
were electrochemically oxidized to form Cu
x
Co
3–
x
O
4
at 1.44 V,
(18)
which is not current of the OER but current of oxide transformation from hydroxide. This phase transformation agreed with the concomitantly observed color change, as depicted in
Figure S9
. The Tafel slope of CCHO was larger than that of CCO because of the presence of residual Co(OH)
2
and/or Cu(OH)
2
on the surface despite electrochemical oxidation.

Compared to CCHO, CCO showed an exceptionally improved catalytic OER activity, exhibiting an overpotential of 290 mV at an electrolytic current density of 10 mA cm
–2
, which was comparable with the activity of previously reported cobaltite catalysts (
Table S1
). Furthermore, CCO maintained its superior activity irrespective of the current density at high overpotentials of >1.6 V, i.e., under conditions typically used for the operation of alkaline water-splitting systems. This behavior was ascribed to the ideal ability of the CCO morphology to transfer vigorously generated oxygen gas and thereby maintain a large active surface area. The long-term stability of CCO was examined by a 24 h operation at current densities of 25 and 100 mA cm
–2
(
Figure
3
c). After 10 h, the sample operated at 25 mA cm
–2
showed a stable overpotential of 380 mV that was only 90 mV higher than the original value. However, the sample operated at 100 mA cm
–2
showed potential fluctuations, which indicated a continuous overpotential distortion due to the accumulation and release of oxygen gas. After stability testing, the samples were immediately subjected to LSV tests to evaluate the catalytic activity changes (
Figure
3
d). For samples operated at 25 and 100 mA cm
–2
, the overpotentials at 10 mA cm
–2
increased by 40 and 50 mV, respectively, compared to values observed before the stability test, while the Tafel slopes of both samples increased to ∼69 mV dec
–1
. Considering the fact that the addition of Cu does not have any effect on the Tafel slope (
Figure
3
b), this behavior was attributed to the physical degradation of the sample nanostructure.

As shown in
Figure
3
e,f, the sample nanostructures degraded after stability testing, possibly because of physical tearing and/or chemical dissolution. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and EDS analysis of stability-tested samples (
Figure S6a–e
) revealed that their SAED patterns and elemental distributions were not significantly different from those of pristine samples. Furthermore, XPS could not provide any evidence of Co dissolution, while the intensity of the Cu peaks was shown to decrease after stability testing (
Figure S7c–e
). This finding strongly implied that the OER activity degradation of CCO was due to the physical tearing of its nanostructure and chemical dissolution of Cu. Therefore, the overpotential and Tafel slope increases were ascribed to chemical dissolution of Cu and the physical tearing of the nanostructure, respectively, although the precise mechanism of CCO degradation remained unclear.

In commercial devices, water electrolysis is performed in a serially connected stack comprising a gas outlet, an anion-exchange membrane (AEM) for gas separation, and an external device promoting electrolyte circulation. Herein, we used CCO as an anode material of an AEM water electrolysis (AEMWE) cell, with details of the cell configuration described in
Figure S8
. Because operation in strongly alkaline solutions is known to result in significant AEM degradation, dilute (0.1 M) KOH was used as an electrolyte. To prevent mechanical damage of the AEM from the sharp edges of the NF substrate, CCO was pressed and then inserted into the AEMWE cell.

The potential shoulder at ∼1.5 V observed in the initial LSV period (
Figure
4
a) probably reflected Ni oxidation (see above) and did not allow us to determine the water electrolysis potential in the region of ∼10 mA cm
–2
. The overpotential of ∼200 mV obtained at a current density of 50 mA cm
–2
was 30 mV smaller than the corresponding value obtained for the half-cell, which was ascribed to differences of the operation conditions such as the cell temperature and Pt loading of the cathode. It was previously reported that the overpotential of an AEMWE cell (i.e., the sum of the OER and hydrogen evolution reaction overpotentials) can be made smaller than that of the half-cell by adjusting operation conditions.
(17)
However, in the high-potential region of >1.8 V, the full-cell current density was much lower than that of the half-cell, which was explained by the sluggish transport of active species caused by the loss of CCO micron-sized porosity after mechanical pressing. In addition, the vigorous generation of gases and their accumulation inside the AEMWE cell might interfere with facile circulation of the electrolyte. Notably, the LSV current density increased with the electrolyte circulation speed, as shown in
Figure S9
; i.e., facile transport of active species was required to promote the AEMWE cell performance. Therefore, the design of AEMWE cells capable of maintaining catalyst layer porosity is an important task for the successful commercialization of the CCO anode in electrolysis devices, which we are currently working on. Finally, the long-term stability of the AEMWE cell was tested at a constant current density of 100 mA cm
–2
at a cell temperature of 30 °C after several LSV tests conducted for stabilization. As shown in
Figure
4
b, the initial overvoltage required for electrolysis equaled 350 mV and increased by only 20 mV after 100 h. For comparison, the results of the half-cell stability tests in 0.1 M KOH are presented in
Figure S10
.

Figure 4. (a) Polarization curves of the AEMWE cell with a CCO anode and a Pt/C (1 mg
Pt
cm
–2
) cathode. (b) Chronopotentiometric curve recorded at a constant current density of 100 mA cm
–2
. 0.1 M KOH was used as an electrolyte, and the cell temperature equaled 30 °C.

In summary, we successfully prepared NF-supported 3D honeycomb-like Cu
0.81
Co
2.19
O
4
nanosheet arrays and tested them as anodes for water splitting under alkaline electrolysis conditions. The above catalyst was shown to contain nano- to micropores and thus featured a very large active surface area and abundant oxygen bubble transport pathways. Importantly, the incorporation of Cu resulted in enhanced OER performance, significantly decreasing the onset potential by increasing the number of active sites and affording an optimal morphology that allowed the successful transfer of oxygen gas away from the surface to maintain good activity during high-rate OER. Thus, coelectrodeposition with Cu can be used to prepare highly porous Co-based nanosheets that can be used in electrochemical devices requiring extremely high catalytic activity for the OER.

A review. Striving for new solar fuels, the water oxidn. reaction currently is considered to be a bottleneck, hampering progress in the development of applicable technologies for the conversion of light into storable fuels. This review compares and unifies viewpoints on water oxidn. from various fields of catalysis research. The first part deals with the thermodn. efficiency and mechanisms of electrochem. water splitting by metal oxides on electrode surfaces, explaining the recent concept of the potential-detg. step. Subsequently, novel cobalt oxide-based catalysts for heterogeneous (electro)catalysis are discussed. These may share structural and functional properties with surface oxides, multinuclear mol. catalysts and the catalytic manganese-calcium complex of photosynthetic water oxidn. Recent developments in homogeneous water-oxidn. catalysis are outlined with a focus on the discovery of mononuclear ruthenium (and non-ruthenium) complexes that efficiently mediate O2 evolution from water. Water oxidn. in photosynthesis is the subject of a concise presentation of structure and function of the natural paragon-the manganese-calcium complex in photosystem II-for which ideas concerning redox-potential leveling, proton removal, and O-O bond formation mechanisms are discussed. The last part highlights common themes and unifying concepts.

It is highly attractive, but still remains a huge challenge, to develop efficient non-noble-metal electrocatalysts for both the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) under neutral and alk. conditions. In this paper, we report that CoP nanosheet arrays on carbon cloth (CoP NA/CC), derived from α-Co(OH)2 NA/CC, behaves as a three-dimensional bifunctional water-splitting catalyst electrode with high activity and durability in neutral and alk. media. Such CoP NA/CC demands overpotentials of 145 and 52 mV to afford 10 mA cm-2 for the HER in 1.0 M phosphate buffer soln. (PBS) and 1.0 M KOH, resp., with much superior activity to α-Co(OH)2 NA/CC. It can be attributed to the more thermo-neutral hydrogen adsorption free energy for CoP than α-Co(OH)2, according to d. functional theory calcns. This electrode also demonstrates superior OER activity over α-Co(OH)2 NA/CC and needs overpotentials of only 536 and 300 mV to drive 10 mA cm-2 at neutral and alk. pH, resp. The two-electrode water electrolyzer using CoP NA/CC as both the cathode and anode shows a 2 mA cm-2 water-splitting current at a cell voltage of 1.60 V in 1.0 M PBS and needs 1.65 V for 10 mA cm-2 under alk. condition with excellent stability.

The mechanism of the O evolution reaction (OER) by catalysts prepd. by electrodepositions from Co2+ solns. in phosphate electrolytes (Co-Pi) was studied at neutral pH by electrokinetic and 18O isotope expts. Low-potential electrodepositions enabled the controlled prepn. of ultrathin Co-Pi catalyst films (<100 nm) that could be studied kinetically in the absence of mass transport and charge transport limitations to the OER. The Co-Pi catalysts exhibit a Tafel slope approx. equal to 2.3 × RT/F for the prodn. of O from H2O in neutral solns. The electrochem. rate law exhibits an inverse 1st order dependence on proton activity and a zeroth order dependence on phosphate for [Pi] ≥ 0.03 M. In the absence of phosphate buffer, the Tafel slope is increased ∼3-fold and the overall activity is greatly diminished. Together, these electrokinetic studies suggest a mechanism involving a rapid, one electron, one proton equil. between CoIII-OH and CoIV-O in which a phosphate species is the proton acceptor, followed by a chem. turnover-limiting process involving O-O bond coupling.

Electrochem. water splitting in alk. soln. plays a growing role in alternative energy devices due to the need for clean and sustainable energy. However, catalysts that are active for both hydrogen evolution and oxygen evolution reactions are rare. Herein, we demonstrate that cobalt phosphide (CoP), which was synthesized via the hydrothermal route and has been shown to have hydrogen evolution activity, is highly active for oxygen evolution. A c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 was generated at an overpotential of only 320 mV in 1 M KOH for a CoP nanorod-based electrode (CoP NR/C), which was competitive with com. IrO2. This high activity was attributed to the formation of a thin layer of ultrafine cryst. cobalt oxide on the CoP surface.

An O evolution catalyst that forms as a thin film from Ni(aq)2+ solns. contg. borate electrolyte (Ni-Bi) was studied by in situ x-ray absorption spectroscopy. A dramatic increase in catalytic rate, induced by anodic activation of the electrodeposited films, is accompanied by structure and oxidn. state changes. Coulometric measurements correlated with x-ray absorption near-edge structure spectra of the active catalyst show that the Ni centers in activated films possess an av. oxidn. state of +3.6, indicating that a substantial proportion of Ni centers exist in a formal oxidn. state of Ni(IV). In contrast, Ni centers in nonactivated films exist predominantly as Ni(III). Extended x-ray absorption fine structure reveals that activated catalyst films comprise bis-oxo/hydroxo-bridged Ni centers organized into sheets of edge-sharing NiO6 octahedra. Diminished long-range ordering in catalyst films is due to their ostensibly amorphous nature. Nonactivated films display a similar oxidic nature but exhibit a distortion in the local coordination geometry about Ni centers, characteristic of Jahn-Teller distorted Ni(III) centers. The authors' findings indicate that the increase in catalytic activity of films is accompanied by changes in oxidn. state and structure that are reminiscent of those obsd. for conversion of β-NiOOH to γ-NiOOH and consequently challenge the long-held notion that the β-NiOOH phase is a more efficient O-evolving catalyst.

Large-scale industrial application of electrolytic splitting of water has called for the development of oxygen evolution electrodes that are inexpensive, robust and can deliver large c.d. (>500 mA cm-2) at low applied potentials. Here we show that an efficient oxygen electrode can be developed by electrodepositing amorphous mesoporous nickel-iron composite nanosheets directly onto macroporous nickel foam substrates. The as-prepd. oxygen electrode exhibits high catalytic activity towards water oxidn. in alk. solns., which only requires an overpotential of 200 mV to initiate the reaction, and is capable of delivering current densities of 500 and 1,000 mA cm-2 at overpotentials of 240 and 270 mV, resp. Collectively, the as-prepd. three-dimensional structured electrode is the most efficient oxygen evolution electrode in alk. electrolytes reported to the best of our knowledge, and can potentially be applied for industrial scale water electrolysis.

20
Nickel selenide as a high-efficiency catalyst for oxygen evolution reaction
Swesi, A. T.; Masud, J.; Nath, M.
Energy & Environmental Science
(
2016
),
9
(
5
),
1771-1782
CODEN:
EESNBY
; ISSN:
1754-5706
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
A metal-rich form of Ni-selenide, nickel subselenide, Ni3Se2 has been investigated as a potential oxygen evolution electrocatalyst under alk. conditions for the first time. The Ni3Se2 phase has a structure similar to the sulfur mineral heazlewoodite, which contains metal-metal bonding. The electrocatalytic activities of Ni3Se2 towards OER were seen to be at par with or even superior to the transition metal oxide based electrocatalyst in terms of onset overpotential for O2 evolution as well as overpotential to reach a c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 (obsd. at 290 mV). The electrocatalytic Ni3Se2 films were grown by electrodeposition on conducting substrates and the deposition parameters including the pH of the electrolytic bath, deposition potential, and substrate compn. were seen to have some influence on the catalytic activity. So far, Ni3Se2 films deposited on the Au-coated Si substrate was seen to have the lowest overpotential. Annealing of the as-deposited electrocatalytic films in an inert atm., enhanced their catalytic efficiencies by decreasing the overpotential (@10 mA cm-2) as well as increasing the c.d. The structure and morphol. of these films has been characterized by powder X-ray diffraction, scanning and transmission electron microscopy, Raman, and XPS. Catalytic activities were investigated through detailed electrochem. studies under alk. conditions, including linear sweep voltammetry, chronoamperometric studies at const. potential, electrochem. surface area detn. and calcn. of the Tafel slope. The Faradaic efficiency of this catalyst has been estd. by reducing the evolved O2 in a RRDE set-up which also confirmed that the evolved gas was indeed O2. In addn. to low overpotentials, these Ni3Se2 electrodeposited films were seen to be exceptionally stable under conditions of continuous O2 evolution for an extended period (42 h).

Dependence of the synthetic strategy on the thermochemical energy storage capability of CuxCo3-xO4 spinels
Tamayo, A.; Rodriguez, Ma. A.; Arroyo, C.; Beltran-Heredia, J.; Rubio, F.
Journal of the European Ceramic Society

CuxCo3-xO4 spinels have been prepd. through three different synthetic approaches to obtain oxide materials where the cationic distribution along the octahedral and tetrahedral sites is modified. The correlation of the spectroscopic characterization techniques and XRD patterns allowed to identify the relative concn. of the cationic species in the coordination environments. The aq. routes favor the intimate contact of the cations and then, the migration of Co(III) to a tetrahedral coordination with Cu incorporation is promoted. This conversion to a partially inverse spinel structure leads to a decrease of the thermochem. capability of the prepd. materials, in terms of energy balance but the O2 release from the structure is favored with the increase in the no. of cations occupying the tetrahedral sites. The endothermic reaction assocd. to the redox transition to CoO occurs in two differentiated steps which can be correlated with the degree of the inversion of the spinel structure.

An Investigation of Thin-Film Ni-Fe Oxide Catalysts for the Electrochemical Evolution of Oxygen
Louie, Mary W.; Bell, Alexis T.
Journal of the American Chemical Society
(
2013
),
135
(
33
),
12329-12337
CODEN:
JACSAT
; ISSN:
0002-7863
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
A detailed study was carried out of the structure and electrochem. activity of electrodeposited Ni-Fe films for the O evolution reaction (OER) in alk. electrolytes. Ni-Fe films with a bulk and surface compn. of 40% Fe exhibit OER activities that are roughly 2 orders of magnitude higher than that of a freshly deposited Ni film and ∼3 orders of magnitude higher than that of an Fe film. The freshly deposited Ni film increases in activity by ≤20-fold during exposure to the electrolyte (KOH); however, all films contg. Fe are stable as deposited. The oxidn. of Ni(OH)2 to NiOOH in Ni films occurs at potentials below the onset of the OER. Incorporation of Fe into the film increases the potential at which Ni(OH)2/NiOOH redox occurs and decreases the av. oxidn. state of Ni in NiOOH. The Tafel slope (40 mV dec-1) and reaction order in OH- (1) for the mixed Ni-Fe films (contg. up to 95% Fe) are the same as those for aged Ni films. In situ Raman spectra acquired in 0.1 M KOH at OER potentials show two bands characteristic of NiOOH. The relative intensities of these bands vary with Fe content, indicating a change in the local environment of Ni-O. Similar changes in the relative intensities of the bands and an increase in OER activity are obsd. when pure Ni films are aged. Probably the OER is catalyzed by Ni in Ni-Fe films and the presence of Fe alters the redox properties of Ni, causing a pos. shift in the potential at which Ni(OH)2/NiOOH redox occurs, a decrease in the av. oxidn. state of the Ni sites, and a concurrent increase in the activity of Ni cations for the OER.

Cyclic voltammetry of copper in sodium hydroxide solutions
Abd El Haleem, S. M.; Ateya, Badr G.
Journal of Electroanalytical Chemistry and Interfacial Electrochemistry
(
1981
),
117
(
2
),
309-19
CODEN:
JEIEBC
; ISSN:
0022-0728
.
The cyclic voltammograms of a Cu electrode were obtained in NaOH soln. asa function of the voltage scanning rate, electrolyte concn., and voltage range. A correlation was made between 3 well-defined anodic peaks and their corresponding cathodic ones. The anodic peaks correspond successively to the formation of a monolayer of Cu2O, formation of a thick multilayer film of CuO and finally Cu2O3 from which O is evolved. It is suggested that CuO is formed from the oxidn. of Cu2O and/or direct oxidn. of metallic Cu. Below 0.1M NaOH the ratio of anodic to cathodic charges was about unity, indicating the quant. redn. of solid oxidn. products, while at higher alkali concns. higher charge ratios were obtained due to increasing proportions of sol. reaction products. The behavior of the Cu electrode in NaOH was quite complicated. Thus, no simple relations were found between the voltage scanning rate and both the peak current and peak potential or between the peak current and the alkali concn. Further work is needed to obtain a definitive explanation of this behavior.

Facile Synthesis of Microsphere Copper Cobalt Carbonate Hydroxides Electrode for Asymmetric Supercapacitor
Liu, Shude; Hui, K. S.; Hui, K. N.; Jadhav, Vijaykumar V.; Xia, Qi Xun; Yun, Je Moon; Cho, Y. R.; Mane, Rajaram S.; Kim, Kwang Ho
Electrochimica Acta
(
2016
),
188
(
),
898-908
CODEN:
ELCAAV
; ISSN:
0013-4686
.
(
Elsevier Ltd.
)
Porous microspheres Cu Co carbonate hydroxides (CuxCo2-xCH) pseudocapacitive electrode material comprised of nanoplates via a facile hydrothermal method were presented. Significantly, the cryst. structure, morphol. and electrochem. performance of the CuxCo2-xCH can be readily manipulated by varying the Cu/Co molar ratios. Among various stoichiometries of CuxCo2-xCH porous microspheres studied, Cu1.79Co0.21CH consisted of nanoplates with a mean thickness of ∼35 nm showed a high specific capacitance of 789 F g-1 at a current destiny of 1 A g-1 and good rate ability. Also, the optimized Cu1.79Co0.21CH electrode also exhibited remarkable high cycling stability, ∼77.5% after 3000 charge/discharge cycles at c.d. of 5 A g-1. An asym. device was constructed from optimized Cu1.79Co0.21CH materials on Ni foam (NF) as cathode electrode and graphene on NF as anode electrode in a 6 M KOH electrolyte. The asym. Cu1.79Co0.21CH/NF//graphene/NF supercapacitor device delivered a specific capacitance of 60.5 F g-1 in a potential range of 0-1.6 V. a high energy d. of 21.5 W h kg-1 was achieved at the power d. of 200 W kg-1. More significantly, the designed device exhibited excellent cycling stability with 73.3% capacity retention after 5000 cycles.

The Mechanism of Water Oxidation: from Electrolysis via Homogeneous to Biological Catalysis
Dau, Holger; Limberg, Christian; Reier, Tobias; Risch, Marcel; Roggan, Stefan; Strasser, Peter
ChemCatChem
(
2010
),

A review. Striving for new solar fuels, the water oxidn. reaction currently is considered to be a bottleneck, hampering progress in the development of applicable technologies for the conversion of light into storable fuels. This review compares and unifies viewpoints on water oxidn. from various fields of catalysis research. The first part deals with the thermodn. efficiency and mechanisms of electrochem. water splitting by metal oxides on electrode surfaces, explaining the recent concept of the potential-detg. step. Subsequently, novel cobalt oxide-based catalysts for heterogeneous (electro)catalysis are discussed. These may share structural and functional properties with surface oxides, multinuclear mol. catalysts and the catalytic manganese-calcium complex of photosynthetic water oxidn. Recent developments in homogeneous water-oxidn. catalysis are outlined with a focus on the discovery of mononuclear ruthenium (and non-ruthenium) complexes that efficiently mediate O2 evolution from water. Water oxidn. in photosynthesis is the subject of a concise presentation of structure and function of the natural paragon-the manganese-calcium complex in photosystem II-for which ideas concerning redox-potential leveling, proton removal, and O-O bond formation mechanisms are discussed. The last part highlights common themes and unifying concepts.

Cost-effective prodn. of solar fuels requires robust and earth-abundant O evolution reaction (OER) catalysts. Herein, the authors report that ultrathin nanoplates of Co-Mn layered double hydroxide (CoMn LDH) are a highly active and stable O evolution catalyst. The catalyst was fabricated by a 1-pot copptn. method at room temp., and its turnover frequency (TOF) is >20 times higher than the TOFs of Co and Mn oxides and hydroxides, and 9 times higher than the TOF of a precious IrO2 catalyst. The activity of the catalyst was promoted by anodic conditioning, which probably forms amorphous regions and reactive Co(IV) species on the surface. The stability of the catalyst was demonstrated by continued electrolysis.

It is highly attractive, but still remains a huge challenge, to develop efficient non-noble-metal electrocatalysts for both the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) under neutral and alk. conditions. In this paper, we report that CoP nanosheet arrays on carbon cloth (CoP NA/CC), derived from α-Co(OH)2 NA/CC, behaves as a three-dimensional bifunctional water-splitting catalyst electrode with high activity and durability in neutral and alk. media. Such CoP NA/CC demands overpotentials of 145 and 52 mV to afford 10 mA cm-2 for the HER in 1.0 M phosphate buffer soln. (PBS) and 1.0 M KOH, resp., with much superior activity to α-Co(OH)2 NA/CC. It can be attributed to the more thermo-neutral hydrogen adsorption free energy for CoP than α-Co(OH)2, according to d. functional theory calcns. This electrode also demonstrates superior OER activity over α-Co(OH)2 NA/CC and needs overpotentials of only 536 and 300 mV to drive 10 mA cm-2 at neutral and alk. pH, resp. The two-electrode water electrolyzer using CoP NA/CC as both the cathode and anode shows a 2 mA cm-2 water-splitting current at a cell voltage of 1.60 V in 1.0 M PBS and needs 1.65 V for 10 mA cm-2 under alk. condition with excellent stability.

The mechanism of the O evolution reaction (OER) by catalysts prepd. by electrodepositions from Co2+ solns. in phosphate electrolytes (Co-Pi) was studied at neutral pH by electrokinetic and 18O isotope expts. Low-potential electrodepositions enabled the controlled prepn. of ultrathin Co-Pi catalyst films (<100 nm) that could be studied kinetically in the absence of mass transport and charge transport limitations to the OER. The Co-Pi catalysts exhibit a Tafel slope approx. equal to 2.3 × RT/F for the prodn. of O from H2O in neutral solns. The electrochem. rate law exhibits an inverse 1st order dependence on proton activity and a zeroth order dependence on phosphate for [Pi] ≥ 0.03 M. In the absence of phosphate buffer, the Tafel slope is increased ∼3-fold and the overall activity is greatly diminished. Together, these electrokinetic studies suggest a mechanism involving a rapid, one electron, one proton equil. between CoIII-OH and CoIV-O in which a phosphate species is the proton acceptor, followed by a chem. turnover-limiting process involving O-O bond coupling.

Electrochem. water splitting in alk. soln. plays a growing role in alternative energy devices due to the need for clean and sustainable energy. However, catalysts that are active for both hydrogen evolution and oxygen evolution reactions are rare. Herein, we demonstrate that cobalt phosphide (CoP), which was synthesized via the hydrothermal route and has been shown to have hydrogen evolution activity, is highly active for oxygen evolution. A c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 was generated at an overpotential of only 320 mV in 1 M KOH for a CoP nanorod-based electrode (CoP NR/C), which was competitive with com. IrO2. The Tafel slope for CoP NR/C was only 71 mV dec-1, and the catalyst maintained high stability during a 12 h test. This high activity was attributed to the formation of a thin layer of ultrafine cryst. cobalt oxide on the CoP surface.

An O evolution catalyst that forms as a thin film from Ni(aq)2+ solns. contg. borate electrolyte (Ni-Bi) was studied by in situ x-ray absorption spectroscopy. A dramatic increase in catalytic rate, induced by anodic activation of the electrodeposited films, is accompanied by structure and oxidn. state changes. Coulometric measurements correlated with x-ray absorption near-edge structure spectra of the active catalyst show that the Ni centers in activated films possess an av. oxidn. state of +3.6, indicating that a substantial proportion of Ni centers exist in a formal oxidn. state of Ni(IV). In contrast, Ni centers in nonactivated films exist predominantly as Ni(III). Extended x-ray absorption fine structure reveals that activated catalyst films comprise bis-oxo/hydroxo-bridged Ni centers organized into sheets of edge-sharing NiO6 octahedra. Diminished long-range ordering in catalyst films is due to their ostensibly amorphous nature. Nonactivated films display a similar oxidic nature but exhibit a distortion in the local coordination geometry about Ni centers, characteristic of Jahn-Teller distorted Ni(III) centers. The authors' findings indicate that the increase in catalytic activity of films is accompanied by changes in oxidn. state and structure that are reminiscent of those obsd. for conversion of β-NiOOH to γ-NiOOH and consequently challenge the long-held notion that the β-NiOOH phase is a more efficient O-evolving catalyst.

; ISSN:
2041-1723
.
(
Nature Publishing Group
)
Large-scale industrial application of electrolytic splitting of water has called for the development of oxygen evolution electrodes that are inexpensive, robust and can deliver large c.d. (>500 mA cm-2) at low applied potentials. Here we show that an efficient oxygen electrode can be developed by electrodepositing amorphous mesoporous nickel-iron composite nanosheets directly onto macroporous nickel foam substrates. The as-prepd. oxygen electrode exhibits high catalytic activity towards water oxidn. in alk. solns., which only requires an overpotential of 200 mV to initiate the reaction, and is capable of delivering current densities of 500 and 1,000 mA cm-2 at overpotentials of 240 and 270 mV, resp. The electrode also shows prolonged stability against bulk water electrolysis at large current. Collectively, the as-prepd. three-dimensional structured electrode is the most efficient oxygen evolution electrode in alk. electrolytes reported to the best of our knowledge, and can potentially be applied for industrial scale water electrolysis.

Nickel selenide as a high-efficiency catalyst for oxygen evolution reaction
Swesi, A. T.; Masud, J.; Nath, M.
Energy & Environmental Science
(

),

CODEN:

A metal-rich form of Ni-selenide, nickel subselenide, Ni3Se2 has been investigated as a potential oxygen evolution electrocatalyst under alk. conditions for the first time. The Ni3Se2 phase has a structure similar to the sulfur mineral heazlewoodite, which contains metal-metal bonding. The electrocatalytic activities of Ni3Se2 towards OER were seen to be at par with or even superior to the transition metal oxide based electrocatalyst in terms of onset overpotential for O2 evolution as well as overpotential to reach a c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 (obsd. at 290 mV). The electrocatalytic Ni3Se2 films were grown by electrodeposition on conducting substrates and the deposition parameters including the pH of the electrolytic bath, deposition potential, and substrate compn. were seen to have some influence on the catalytic activity. So far, Ni3Se2 films deposited on the Au-coated Si substrate was seen to have the lowest overpotential. Annealing of the as-deposited electrocatalytic films in an inert atm., enhanced their catalytic efficiencies by decreasing the overpotential (@10 mA cm-2) as well as increasing the c.d. The structure and morphol. of these films has been characterized by powder X-ray diffraction, scanning and transmission electron microscopy, Raman, and XPS. Catalytic activities were investigated through detailed electrochem. studies under alk. conditions, including linear sweep voltammetry, chronoamperometric studies at const. potential, electrochem. surface area detn. and calcn. of the Tafel slope. The Faradaic efficiency of this catalyst has been estd. by reducing the evolved O2 in a RRDE set-up which also confirmed that the evolved gas was indeed O2. In addn. to low overpotentials, these Ni3Se2 electrodeposited films were seen to be exceptionally stable under conditions of continuous O2 evolution for an extended period (42 h).

CuxCo3-xO4 spinels have been prepd. through three different synthetic approaches to obtain oxide materials where the cationic distribution along the octahedral and tetrahedral sites is modified. The correlation of the spectroscopic characterization techniques and XRD patterns allowed to identify the relative concn. of the cationic species in the coordination environments. The aq. routes favor the intimate contact of the cations and then, the migration of Co(III) to a tetrahedral coordination with Cu incorporation is promoted. This conversion to a partially inverse spinel structure leads to a decrease of the thermochem. capability of the prepd. materials, in terms of energy balance but the O2 release from the structure is favored with the increase in the no. of cations occupying the tetrahedral sites. The endothermic reaction assocd. to the redox transition to CoO occurs in two differentiated steps which can be correlated with the degree of the inversion of the spinel structure.

An Investigation of Thin-Film Ni-Fe Oxide Catalysts for the Electrochemical Evolution of Oxygen
Louie, Mary W.; Bell, Alexis T.

A detailed study was carried out of the structure and electrochem. activity of electrodeposited Ni-Fe films for the O evolution reaction (OER) in alk. electrolytes. Ni-Fe films with a bulk and surface compn. of 40% Fe exhibit OER activities that are roughly 2 orders of magnitude higher than that of a freshly deposited Ni film and ∼3 orders of magnitude higher than that of an Fe film. The freshly deposited Ni film increases in activity by ≤20-fold during exposure to the electrolyte (KOH); however, all films contg. Fe are stable as deposited. The oxidn. of Ni(OH)2 to NiOOH in Ni films occurs at potentials below the onset of the OER. Incorporation of Fe into the film increases the potential at which Ni(OH)2/NiOOH redox occurs and decreases the av. oxidn. state of Ni in NiOOH. The Tafel slope (40 mV dec-1) and reaction order in OH- (1) for the mixed Ni-Fe films (contg. up to 95% Fe) are the same as those for aged Ni films. In situ Raman spectra acquired in 0.1 M KOH at OER potentials show two bands characteristic of NiOOH. The relative intensities of these bands vary with Fe content, indicating a change in the local environment of Ni-O. Similar changes in the relative intensities of the bands and an increase in OER activity are obsd. when pure Ni films are aged. Probably the OER is catalyzed by Ni in Ni-Fe films and the presence of Fe alters the redox properties of Ni, causing a pos. shift in the potential at which Ni(OH)2/NiOOH redox occurs, a decrease in the av. oxidn. state of the Ni sites, and a concurrent increase in the activity of Ni cations for the OER.

Cyclic voltammetry of copper in sodium hydroxide solutions
Abd El Haleem, S. M.; Ateya, Badr G.
Journal of Electroanalytical Chemistry and Interfacial Electrochemistry
(
1981
),
117
(
2
),
309-19
CODEN:
JEIEBC
; ISSN:
0022-0728
.
The cyclic voltammograms of a Cu electrode were obtained in NaOH soln. asa function of the voltage scanning rate, electrolyte concn., and voltage range. A correlation was made between 3 well-defined anodic peaks and their corresponding cathodic ones. The anodic peaks correspond successively to the formation of a monolayer of Cu2O, formation of a thick multilayer film of CuO and finally Cu2O3 from which O is evolved. It is suggested that CuO is formed from the oxidn. of Cu2O and/or direct oxidn. of metallic Cu. Below 0.1M NaOH the ratio of anodic to cathodic charges was about unity, indicating the quant. redn. of solid oxidn. products, while at higher alkali concns. higher charge ratios were obtained due to increasing proportions of sol. reaction products. The behavior of the Cu electrode in NaOH was quite complicated. Thus, no simple relations were found between the voltage scanning rate and both the peak current and peak potential or between the peak current and the alkali concn. Further work is needed to obtain a definitive explanation of this behavior.

Liu, Shude; Hui, K. S.; Hui, K. N.; Jadhav, Vijaykumar V.; Xia, Qi Xun; Yun, Je Moon; Cho, Y. R.; Mane, Rajaram S.; Kim, Kwang Ho

Porous microspheres Cu Co carbonate hydroxides (CuxCo2-xCH) pseudocapacitive electrode material comprised of nanoplates via a facile hydrothermal method were presented. Significantly, the cryst. structure, morphol. and electrochem. performance of the CuxCo2-xCH can be readily manipulated by varying the Cu/Co molar ratios. Among various stoichiometries of CuxCo2-xCH porous microspheres studied, Cu1.79Co0.21CH consisted of nanoplates with a mean thickness of ∼35 nm showed a high specific capacitance of 789 F g-1 at a current destiny of 1 A g-1 and good rate ability. Also, the optimized Cu1.79Co0.21CH electrode also exhibited remarkable high cycling stability, ∼77.5% after 3000 charge/discharge cycles at c.d. of 5 A g-1. An asym. device was constructed from optimized Cu1.79Co0.21CH materials on Ni foam (NF) as cathode electrode and graphene on NF as anode electrode in a 6 M KOH electrolyte. The asym. Cu1.79Co0.21CH/NF//graphene/NF supercapacitor device delivered a specific capacitance of 60.5 F g-1 in a potential range of 0-1.6 V. a high energy d. of 21.5 W h kg-1 was achieved at the power d. of 200 W kg-1. More significantly, the designed device exhibited excellent cycling stability with 73.3% capacity retention after 5000 cycles.
